Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Thrust Belt Response to Rapid Surface Uplift of the Altiplano: A Field Test of Cordilleran Cyclicity in Southern Bolivia
Award.AbstractNarration: The Cordilleran cyclicity model predicts that detachment of dense continental lithosphere should be accompanied by rapid uplift of an orogenic plateau and resulting rapid advance of deformation in the frontal fold-thrust belt. In the central Andean plateau, recent isotopic studies argue for rapid surface uplift of the southern Altiplano in Bolivia between 16 and 13 million years ago, which has been attributed to removal of dense material at depth. The Cordilleran cyclicity model predicts that the Andean fold-thrust belt should have responded to this rapid uplift event through rapid eastward propagation of the deformation front. However, accurate records of the timing and magnitude of deformation in the thrust belt in southern Bolivia are not available, which leaves this key prediction untested. In this project, we are performing a field-based study aimed at documenting the response (or lack thereof) of the Andean fold-thrust belt to the rapid rise of the hinterland plateau. The project involves geologic mapping along an east-west transect through the thrust belt in southern Bolivia, which will support construction of a balanced cross-section. By sequentially restoring deformation in the cross-section, we are generating a record of shortening over the last ~20-30 million years. This record will be integrated with deformation timing constraints from analysis of field relationships of sedimentary rocks deposited during crustal shortening, and timing estimates for erosion of multiple thrust sheets obtained from low-temperature cooling histories. The final goal of the project will be to generate a timing record of forward propagation rates of the thrust front and of contemporaneous depositional centers. Together, these records will allow us to evaluate the orogenic response to rapid hinterland surface uplift, and therefore to test a key prediction of the Cordilleran cyclicity model. This project is training graduate and undergraduate students (including a Bolivian graduate student studying in the U.S.) in a STEM field, and is contributing to the broadening of representation of underrepresented groups in the earth sciences; it is facilitating a new collaboration between U.S. investigators at two institutions (University of Nevada Reno and the University of Texas at Austin); and it is fostering a valuable international collaboration between U.S. and Bolivian scientists. This award is being co-funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Models proposed for continental mountain belts such as the Andes seek to describe the relationships between several processes that operated during their construction. In the Andes in southern Bolivia, recent studies propose that the Altiplano, the present-day high plateau, rapidly rose to its current elevation at about 13 million years ago. A recent model for mountain belts, called the Cordilleran cyclicity model, predicts that this rapid uplift event should have resulted in measurable changes in the Andean thrust belt, which is the actively-growing part of the Andes situated to the east of the Altiplano. Specifically, the model predicts that the thrust belt should have responded to this uplift event through rapid eastward (cratonward) advance. However, accurate records of the timing, magnitude, and rates of deformation in the Andes in southern Bolivia are not available, so this critical prediction of the Cordilleran cyclicity model remains untested.

The goal of this project was to document the response (or lack thereof) of the Andean thrust belt to the rapid rise of the Altiplano. To perform this test required assembly of a detailed record of the geometry of the Andean thrust belt, and constraining the timing of its progressive construction over much of the last 30 million years. To achieve this, we first made a geologic map of a 300 km-wide, east-west transect through the Andean thrust belt in southern Bolivia. The geologic map was used to support the construction of a cross-section, which is an east-west trending, vertical slice through the mountain belt, which illustrates the geometry of the faults and folds that make up the thrust belt. We drew the cross-section in such a way that the horizontal shortening accommodated by individual faults and folds can be progressively restored. By performing this restoration for all faults and folds, we generated an illustration of the original dimensions of the rocks that were shortened and thickened to construct the Andes. Our restoration shows that the Andes in southern Bolivia were constructed by a total of ~340 km of horizontal, east-west shortening of the western part of the South American continental plate. This deformation thickened the crust under the Andes to as much as ~60-70 km, which is nearly twice as much as its original thickness.

In order to estimate the rates at which the Andean thrust belt migrated forward over the last 30 million years, the next step of the project involved sequentially deforming the cross-section back to its present-day geometry, and integrating constraints on the timing of fault motion and fold growth. The first technique that we used to obtain timing constraints involved accurately dating the timing of rock cooling, which we can relate to erosion initiated by fault motion and fold growth. Using two different techniques that utilize the minerals zircon and apatite, we collected records of the timing and rates that rocks cooled from ~180 to ~60 °C, which we can relate to the timing of the faults that brought these rocks from several kilometers depth to the present-day surface. We collected these data for 53 rock samples, which span the width of the Andean thrust belt.

The second technique that we used to constrain the timing of Andean deformation involved the analysis of field relationships and dating of sedimentary rocks deposited during construction of the Andes. Analyses of Cenozoic depositional environments, sediment provenance, and stratigraphic ages (through a combination of measured sedimentary sections and detrital zircon U-Pb geochronology) have allowed the identification of key phases of basin evolution during activity along several fold-thrust structures. These results show that shifts in sediment source regions and sediment accumulation patterns can be tied to the growth of particular structural elements (specifically, the Eastern Cordillera, Interandean Zone, and Subandean Zone) of the Andean thrust belt.

Finally, by integrating sequential deformation of faults and folds from the cross-section with the timing constraints from cooling histories and from the sedimentary rocks, we were able to generate a record of the rates of forward motion of the front of the Andean mountain belt for the past ~30 million years. Our results, though preliminary, do not support a rapid eastward propagation of the thrust belt during or immediately after rapid uplift of the Altiplano ~13 million years ago, which is predicted by the Cordilleran cyclicity model. Instead, we suggest that different factors, including the relative strength of rocks that the Andean thrust belt migrated eastward through, played a more significant role in the construction history of the mountain belt.

This project involved training of two Ph.D. students, one at Washington State University, and one at the University of Texas, Austin. In addition, this project also involved collaboration with Bolivian scientists.
